sn45.12:1.2: “Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for three months.
sn45.12:1.3: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my alms-food.”
sn45.12:1.4: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the alms-food.
sn45.12:2.1: Then after three months had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:
sn45.12:2.2: “Mendicants, I’ve been practicing part of the meditation I practiced when I was first awakened.
sn45.12:2.4: there’s feeling conditioned by wrong view
sn45.12:2.5: and by the stilling of wrong view,
sn45.12:2.7: and by the stilling of right view. …
sn45.12:2.8: There’s feeling conditioned by wrong immersion
sn45.12:2.9: and by the stilling of wrong immersion, by right immersion
sn45.12:2.10: and by the stilling of right immersion.
sn45.12:2.12: and by the stilling of desire,
sn45.12:2.14: and by the stilling of thought,
sn45.12:2.16: and by the stilling of perception.
sn45.12:2.17: As long as desire, thought, and perception are not stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.
sn45.12:2.18: When desire, thought, and perception are stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.
sn45.12:2.19: There is effort to attain the unattained. When that state has been attained, there is also feeling conditioned by that.”
